mn143:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn143:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn143:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
mn143:2.1.eng: Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
mn143:2.1.comm: Renowned as the foremost of benefactors, Anāthapiṇḍika appears in over twenty discourses in the Saṁyutta and Aṅguttara Nikāyas, discussing matters such as generosity, guarding the mind, and the development of meditation; the story of his conversion is recorded in the Vinaya (Kd 16:4.1.1). He is well known for his offering of the monastery at which the Buddha most often stayed, but this discourse marks his only personal appearance in the Majjhima.

mn143:2.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:

mn143:2.3.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn143:2.3.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

mn143:2.4.eng: ‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn143:2.5.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

mn143:2.6.pli: Yena cāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato sāriputtassa pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn143:2.6.eng: Then go to Venerable Sāriputta, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

mn143:2.7.eng: ‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn143:2.8.pli: So āyasmato sāriputtassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
mn143:2.8.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

mn143:2.10.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto yena anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
mn143:2.10.eng: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of sympathy.’”

mn143:2.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so puriso anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn143:2.11.eng: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Anāthapiṇḍika asked.

mn143:2.14.pli: Yena cāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:

mn143:2.16.pli: So āyasmato sāriputtassa pāde sirasā vandati;

mn143:2.18.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto yena anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

mn143:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya āyasmatā ānandena pacchāsamaṇena yena anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho āyasmā sāriputto anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
mn143:3.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went with Venerable Ānanda as his second monk to Anāthapiṇḍika’s home. He sat down on the seat spread out, and said to Anāthapiṇḍika,

mn143:3.2.pli: “kacci te, gahapati, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ? Kacci te dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
mn143:3.2.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, householder; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
mn143:3.2.comm: The sick Anāthapiṇḍika was consoled by Ānanda at SN 55.27:3.2 and by Sāriputta at SN 55.26:4.2. in other cases, we find the Buddha making such visits to sick monks (SN 22.87:2.7, SN 22.88:2.8, SN 46.14:2.1, SN 46.15:2.1, AN 6.56:2.1), but for some reason visits to householders are only attested for Sāriputta (MN 97:28.2) or Ānanda (SN 47.29:2.2).

mn143:4.1.pli: “Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.
mn143:4.1.eng: “I’m not keeping well, Honorable Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident.

mn143:4.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante sāriputta, balavā puriso tiṇhena sikharena muddhani abhimattheyya; evameva kho me, bhante sāriputta, adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.
mn143:4.2.eng: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.

mn143:4.3.pli: Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

mn143:4.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante sāriputta, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakhaṇḍena sīse sīsaveṭhaṃ dadeyya; evameva kho me, bhante sāriputta, adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā.
mn143:4.4.eng: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a strong leather strap around my head.

mn143:4.5.pli: Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

mn143:4.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante sāriputta, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā tiṇhena govikantanena kucchiṃ parikanteyya; evameva kho me, bhante sāriputta, adhimattā vātā kucchiṃ parikantanti.
mn143:4.6.eng: The winds slicing my belly are so severe, like a deft butcher or their apprentice were slicing open a cows’s belly with a sharp meat cleaver.

mn143:4.7.pli: Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

mn143:4.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante sāriputta, dve balavanto purisā dubbalataraṃ purisaṃ nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuyā santāpeyyuṃ, samparitāpeyyuṃ; evameva kho me, bhante sāriputta, adhimatto kāyasmiṃ ḍāho.
mn143:4.8.eng: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals. That’s how severe the burning is in my body.

mn143:4.9.pli: Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
mn143:4.9.eng: I’m not keeping well, Honorable Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident.”

mn143:5.1.eng: “That’s why, householder, you should train like this:

mn143:5.2.pli: ‘na cakkhuṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me cakkhunissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:5.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the eye, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the eye.’
mn143:5.2.comm: The teaching on the six senses typically begins by establishing awareness on the reality of the eye (etc.) as something that is grasped at (eg. MN 145:3.1). Here Sāriputta skips over this straight to letting go, signfying that his teaching starts with an advanced level of insight.

mn143:5.5.pli: ‘na sotaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me sotanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:5.5.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the ear, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the ear.’ …

mn143:5.8.pli: ‘na ghānaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me ghānanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:5.8.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the nose, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the nose.’ …

mn143:5.11.pli: ‘na jivhaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me jivhānissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:5.11.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the tongue, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the tongue.’ …

mn143:5.14.pli: ‘na kāyaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me kāyanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:5.14.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the body, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the body.’ …

mn143:5.17.pli: ‘na manaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me manonissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:5.17.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the mind, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the mind.’

mn143:6.2.pli: ‘na rūpaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me rūpanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:6.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp sight, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on sight.’ …

mn143:6.9.pli: na dhammaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me dhammanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:6.9.eng: idea, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on idea.’

mn143:7.2.pli: ‘na cakkhuviññāṇaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me cakkhuviññāṇanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:7.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp eye consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on eye consciousness.’ …

mn143:7.9.pli: na manoviññāṇaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me manoviññāṇanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:7.9.eng: mind consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on mind consciousness.’

mn143:8.2.pli: ‘na cakkhusamphassaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me cakkhusamphassanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.

mn143:8.9.pli: na manosamphassaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me manosamphassanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:8.9.eng: mind contact, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on mind contact.’

mn143:9.2.pli: ‘na cakkhusamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me cakkhusamphassajāvedanānissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:9.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp feeling born of eye contact …

mn143:9.9.pli: na manosamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me manosamphassajāvedanānissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:9.9.eng: feeling born of mind contact, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the feeling born of mind contact.’

mn143:10.2.pli: ‘na pathavīdhātuṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me pathavīdhātunissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:10.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the earth element …

mn143:10.9.pli: na viññāṇadhātuṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me viññāṇadhātunissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:10.9.eng: consciousness element, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the consciousness element.’

mn143:11.2.pli: ‘na rūpaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me rūpanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.

mn143:11.8.pli: na viññāṇaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me viññāṇanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:11.8.eng: consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on consciousness.’

mn143:12.2.pli: ‘na ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me ākāsānañcāyatananissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:12.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the dimension of infinite space …

mn143:12.7.pli: na nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me nevasaññānāsaññāyatananissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:12.7.eng: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn143:13.2.pli: ‘na idhalokaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me idhalokanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:13.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp this world, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on this world.’

mn143:14.2.pli: ‘na paralokaṃ upādiyissāmi, na ca me paralokanissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:14.2.eng: ‘I shall not grasp the other world, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the other world.’

mn143:14.5.pli: ‘yampi me diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anupariyesitaṃ anucaritaṃ manasā tampi na upādiyissāmi, na ca me tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn143:14.5.eng: ‘I shall not grasp whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by my mind, and my consciousness will not have that as support.’

mn143:15.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati parodi, assūni pavattesi.
mn143:15.1.eng: When he said this, Anāthapiṇḍika cried and burst out in tears.

mn143:15.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:

mn143:15.3.pli: “olīyasi kho tvaṃ, gahapati, saṃsīdasi kho tvaṃ, gahapatī”ti?
mn143:15.3.eng: “Are you failing, householder? Are you fading, householder?”

mn143:15.5.pli: api ca me dīgharattaṃ satthā payirupāsito manobhāvanīyā ca bhikkhū;
mn143:15.5.eng: But for a long time I have paid homage to the Buddha and the esteemed mendicants.

mn143:15.6.pli: na ca me evarūpī dhammī kathā sutapubbā”ti.
mn143:15.6.eng: Yet I have never before heard such a Dhamma talk.”

mn143:15.7.pli: “Na kho, gahapati, gihīnaṃ odātavasanānaṃ evarūpī dhammī kathā paṭibhāti;
mn143:15.7.eng: “Householder, such Dhamma talk does not strike when teaching white-clothed laypeople.
mn143:15.7.comm: The verb here is paṭibhāti, the spontaneous striking of inspiration. Sāriputta is not saying such talks are never given, but that such topics are not what comes to mind when teaching laypeople.

mn143:15.8.pli: pabbajitānaṃ kho, gahapati, evarūpī dhammī kathā paṭibhātī”ti.
mn143:15.8.eng: Rather, it strikes when teaching those gone forth.”

mn143:15.9.pli: “Tena hi, bhante sāriputta, gihīnampi odātavasanānaṃ evarūpī dhammī kathā paṭibhātu.
mn143:15.9.eng: “Well then, Honorable Sāriputta, let such Dhamma talk strike when teaching white-clothed laypeople as well!

mn143:15.10.pli: Santi hi, bhante, kulaputtā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti;
mn143:15.10.eng: There are gentlemen with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

mn143:15.11.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!”

mn143:16.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca ānando anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃsu.
mn143:16.1.eng: And when the venerables Sāriputta and Ānanda had given the householder Anāthapiṇḍika this advice they got up from their seat and left.

mn143:16.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati, acirapakkante āyasmante ca sāriputte āyasmante ca ānande, kālamakāsi tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapajji.
mn143:16.2.eng: Not long after they had left, Anāthapiṇḍika passed away and was reborn in the host of joyful gods.

mn143:17.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
mn143:17.1.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Anāthapiṇḍika, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

mn143:17.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho anāthapiṇḍiko devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
mn143:17.2.eng: and addressed the Buddha in verse:

mn143:17.4.eng: frequented by the Saṅgha of seers,

mn143:17.5.eng: where the King of Dhamma stayed:

mn143:17.14.eng: and thus be purified in it.

mn143:17.17.eng: Even a mendicant who has crossed over

mn143:18.1.eng: This is what the godling Anāthapiṇḍika said,

mn143:18.4.pli: “samanuñño me satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
mn143:18.4.eng: knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

mn143:19.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn143:19.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

mn143:19.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ aññataro devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.

mn143:19.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so devaputto maṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:

mn143:19.21.pli: ‘Samanuñño me satthā’ti maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.

mn143:20.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn143:20.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

mn143:20.2.pli: “so hi nūna so, bhante, anāthapiṇḍiko devaputto bhavissati.
mn143:20.2.eng: “Sir, that godling must surely have been Anāthapiṇḍika.

mn143:20.3.pli: Anāthapiṇḍiko, bhante, gahapati āyasmante sāriputte abhippasanno ahosī”ti.
mn143:20.3.eng: For the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was devoted to Venerable Sāriputta.”

mn143:20.5.pli: Yāvatakaṃ kho, ānanda, takkāya pattabbaṃ, anuppattaṃ taṃ tayā.
mn143:20.5.eng: You’ve reached the logical conclusion, as far as logic goes.

mn143:20.6.eng: For that was indeed the godling Anāthapiṇḍika.”

mn143:20.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn143:20.8.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn143:20.8.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
